column1: As a Fabric maintainer, I want gofmt to be checked by the fabric-chaincode-go CI jobs.
column25:
The CI for fabric-chaincode-go currently only does vet and test, no gofmt.  Rather than requiring reviewers to catch deviations from the gofmt manually, having CI do it would be a better option.

{{gofmt}}  and {{goimports}}; If either would result in a change, the build should fail.

Installing {{goimports}} should make use of the {{tools.go}} pattern to ensure we're installing a known version; Alternatively, use a docker image that has the correct versions of the tools pre-populated. In this case, the Dockerfile required to build the container should be placed in the {{ci}} folder, the image pushed with an appropriately versioned tag, and the pipeline definition updated to point to the build container.  (This is a lot like what's done in fabric-protos for build.)
column45: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: create chaincode server (no TLS)
column25: Create chancode server and hook it up to shim. On connection establishment, the chaincode server will go through the same handshake process with the peer.

column1: prepare shim to be a chaincode server
column25: The only difference from gRPC point-of-view between the chaincode-as-client (original) and chaincode-as-server model is the passed in stream does not implement CloseSend for the latter. We adjust the interfaces to accommodate both models.

column65:
1. replace file chaincode_example02.go with the attached file.
2. start the network using    #: ./byfn.sh up
3. when docker container of cli starts then enter into that container using below command in new terminal
#: docker exec -it cli bash

4. before tutorial reach to invoke section of transaction add module
github.com/google/gofuzz into the cli container (which is opened in new terminal) 
using following command :
 #: go get github.com/google/gofuzz

5. Now error can be seen as mentioned above

column96: 05/Dec/19 4:33 AM;jyellick;Agreed that any sample chaincodes should properly check arg lengths before dereferencing.  From a security perspective, such a mistake is mostly a DoS vector, as the chaincode crashing affects the liveness of that chaincode, but it will be restarted.  Fortunately, authorization checks are made well before the chaincode processing begins, so to exploit such a DoS vector requires minimally that the attacker be authorized to invoke the chaincode.;;;

column1: Fabric go cid interface enhancement throw nil error/return nil when idemix msp
column25:
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/release-1.4/core/chaincode/shim/ext/cid/cid.go#L101

When chaincode invoking this function, it depends on cert of user who submit the transaction.
However, considering in idemix type msp. 
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/release-1.4/core/chaincode/shim/ext/cid/cid.go#L105
Will raise a nil exception which not handled or been throw.
Chaincode will exit in error code.

As cid interface having error type in interface definition,  should throw nil error or return nil.
func (c *clientIdentityImpl) GetID() (string, error) 
Instead of chaincode exit with error code.

column1: Add HasOUValue function to cid library
column25:
Public CAs do not support the inclusion of extra extension attributes like the one used for chaincode access control in Fabric that had OID "1.2.3.4.5.6.7.8.1".

This obliges the use of Fabric-CA to be able to use certificate attributes with the cid library. For some organizations it is not allowed by the security department to use Fabric-CA and they prefer to use other CA services.

Access control in the chaincode could also be done by using other fields in the certificates, like for example the OU field of the subject. The advantage of using the OU field is that it is a standard x509 field and that the distinguished name of a x509 certificate subject can have multiple OU values.

The objective of this Jira story is to add a method in the cid library that looks for a specified OU value in the certificate of the transaction sender so the cid library can also be used for access control based on OU values and people do not have to write their custom function for it.

Link to public one pager with more information: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/18QvdmHLXmTgwmjYwawKcWyzJl_vegqh6NgppDV_xmQI/edit?usp=sharing]
column31: Created the Jira story, wrote the one pager, implemented the functionality and unit tests and created a pull request.;06/Jan/20 3:05 PM;braduf;7200

column1: Chaincode definiation exist but not installed hyperledger fabric 2.2
column25:
Hi Team,

I have a kubernetes setup of HLF2.2 with Golang Chaincode and Nodejs SDK.
 I am performing load test on the network, when i try with 250 Concurrent thread, it shows unexpectedly chaincode installation Error. (*Error: Chaincode definiation exist but not found, make sure it's Installed properly*)

Node SDK not able to find any endorsement peer for provided chaincode and throw Exception.

After inspecting I found that
 * 3 out 4 Peer's ledger were crashed.
 * Peer disconnects from channel.
 * It was not showing installed Chain-code. 
 * unable to Query or Invoke from Cli.

I tried restarting the cluster but no luck.

Then I had to re-Install new version of chaincode on Peer's, and it's working fine now.

I am bit worried about the robustness of HLF network and which is not giving me enough confidence to use it in production.

And *also there is no mechanism to monitor container of Chaincode in kubernetes, as it does not show-up in the pods list.* And even i am not sure how much of load is on Chain-code when performing load test.

I have allocated 4GB RAM and 2-Core CPU to each Peer. is that enough for production level setup.
How can we ensure that Chain-code's container gets enough resource allocation. Should I increase my peers RAM further.
column45: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column90:
08/May/21 4:21 AM;denyeart;You were probably hitting the issue *FAB-18194* about incorrect chaincode installation message after peers restart that was fixed in v2.2.1.

For the questions about Kubernetes, there is no built-in support in open source Fabric. Some vendors such as IBM blockchain platform have added support in their offering which uses the external chaincode builder to create and manage chaincode containers.;;;

column1: DelState
column25:
Hi

I'm trying to use DelState for set isDelete to true to my Asset in blockchain.

The asset key is the field codeline.

The operatione is done without error but, when call stub.GetHistoryForKey for the same key,

I found two transactions:

one with normal Asset and the second one with isDelete to true and value null.

 
 {
     "response": "OK",
     "data": [
         {
             "TxId": "8786d051b8861edb62da197966d720c7ca416b639d725c2ab1b6719ad1a6943a",
             "Value": 

{                 "doctype": "Bollettino",                 "timestamp": 1605291770132,                 "codeline": "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX01",                 "tipocreazione": "0",                 "entemittente": "09999",                 "datascadenza": "",                 "datapagamento": "",                 "importo": 0,                 "importopagato": 0,                 "datavaluta": "",                 "datacontabile": "",                 "tipobollettino": "",                 "cc": "",                 "stato": "CREATO",                 "organization": "egl",                 "operatore": "system",                 "sync": ""             }

,
             "Timestamp": "2020-11-13 18:22:28.29 +0000 UTC",
             "IsDelete": "false"
         },
         

{             "TxId": "7755313a0d1c06b633c4726dcf2d7626848b8bd63a18eb58d8fef209cf865a3d",             "Value": null,             "Timestamp": "2020-11-13 18:23:09.44 +0000 UTC",             "IsDelete": "true"         }

    ]
 }
  
 Why ?
 Can you help me ?
  
 Thanks in advance
 Paolo Bruno
column45: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column90: 07/May/21 9:31 PM;denyeart;When you delete it is deleted from state database. Both the original transaction and the delete transaction remain on the blockchain however, so that you can see them when you query the history, e.g. for auditing.;;;

column1: Chaincode build failed in new version of Docker.
column25:
The chainCode build image relies on accessing “/var/run/docker.sock”, which is no longer available:

There is no longer access the docker engine, /var/run/docker.sock, or use Docker-in-Docker (DinD) in latest version of Docker

 

Is there any other way where peer can build chaincode at runtime.
column45: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: DelPrivateData function in a mockstub.go file not implemented
column45: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: (CVE ) Vulnerability in fabric-chaincode-go module
column25:
There is a vulnerability in one of the dependencies of fabric-chaincode-go.

It is in the package golang.org/x/text/ upto version 0.3.3.

Below is the nvd link for the same 

[https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-14040]

 

In go.sum file we can see 0.3.0 version of this package is getting used at 4th or 5th level

golang.org/x/text v0.3.0.

 

In order to fix this issue, can we update the particular dependency of fabric-chaincode-go which is bringing in this version of golang.org/x/text ?
column45: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Unable to get Transaction Details with GetTransactionByID qscc call from another chaincode
column25:
We recently upgraded our Fabric version from 1.4 to 2.3. In our Chaincode we have business logic to verify a txnId is present in ledger or not. With Fabric 2.3 upgrade we are getting below error. If this is a limitation from added in 2.x to avoid deadlock situation, can you let us know the approaches to get transaction details for a given transaction ID from a chaincode? 

Code:
    ~chainCodeArgs := toChaincodeArgs("GetTransactionByID", stub.GetChannelID(), tid)~
     ~response := stub.InvokeChaincode("qscc", chainCodeArgs, stub.GetChannelID())~
Error:
~{{Rejecting invoke of QSCC from another chaincode because of potential for deadlocks, original invocation for 'testcc'}}~
column45: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column65:
Invoke GetTransactionByID from another chaincode as mentioned below. 
Steps:
1. Install & instantiate chaincode TestUserCC
2. Invoke transaction with asset x to call contract A whose transaction ID is 12345
3. Now, invoke another transaction with asset y by checking x exists via Contract B ( GetTransactionByID qscc call here to check x fails)
column90: 05/Jul/21 11:21 AM;KameshPalani;Hi, can you let me know regarding this ticket? ;;;
